section.name: Current Release: 7.09 (stable)
section.p: This page describes technical details of SyMBA. For more general information please see the home page .

p.font: There is currently a problem with the server running the SyMBA sandbox. It should be back up and running sometime next week. We apologize for any inconvenience.

section.p: We are pleased to announce that SyMBA is pretty stable and available in a public sandbox version. Please note that the configuration at this url, while representing the first stable release, remains a sandbox configuration, and any data you may upload to the server may be deleted at any time. We will, however, try to send out warning emails prior to any deletion of the database. As a sandbox implementation, it should not be used as a permanent archive for any data. If you wish to have an archive to store your high-throughput data, please contact us to see if we could collaborate in any way.

subsection.name: Logging In
subsection.p: You will need a logon to access this database, which you may request from the helpdesk . This is a low-level of security that will only serve to prevent anonymous load on the database and to keep your sandbox area separate from others.

subsection.name: What we mean by a 'sandbox' release
subsection.p: We reserve the right to stop and restart the DPI server at any time, and to drop and re-create the database at any time. You should not attempt to use this service as a long-term, permanent store. However, we encourage you to upload data and create as many experiments as you like so that you may determine if this application may be of use to your own research group. We also appreciate you contacting us with any comments or questions you may have.

Further, although we do have an LSID Resolution Service running via http://elephant.ncl.ac.uk:8081/authority , and we do aim to ensure that object returned will always return the same thing, not every object identified with an LSID can currently be resolved via this service. This is still within the standard: if something resolves, it must always be to the same thing. However, you are free to test the LSID server now. More information on contacting the LSID Resolution Service will be added shortly, together with an example Java class.

section.name: Standards Used
section.p: Our back-end, and the XML produced by the front-end, is completely FuGE-compliant . CISBAN is part of the RSBI Consortium , which encourages the use of three main reporting standards for biological investigations: FuGE , OBI , and MIBBI . FuGE is a maturing standard data model for storing experimental metadata, OBI is a developing standard ontology for biological/biomedical experiments, and MIBBI is a new effort to standardize the minimum information needed to describe a biological experiment.

section.name: What does the release number mean?
section.p: We have based the release numbering system on the Ubuntu style. This means that the number prefixing the "." is the year of the release, and the number after the "." is the month of the release. Therefore, release 7.03 was released in March 2007. Finally, we add a comment after the release number detailing whether the release is a beta version or a stable version.

section.name: Does this project suit your needs?
section.p: We are interested in collaboration with any group that may be able to make use of this project. Most aspects of the application are generic, and the main way of customizing the DPI is via creation and upload of your own experimental protocols.

section.name: What are we planning in future?

ul.li: A Protocol Wizard for adding protocols via the gui rather than the command line
An ontology term tracker that could automatically add terms to the interface, as this is the main way the experimental factors are stored.
Upgrade of the system to FuGE Version 1 (and therefore UML 2), once it has been finalized.
Upgrade of the build system to Maven 2 ( completed ) and AndroMDA 4.
Download of the entire system so that others may install it for their own use.
An Administration page that allows a view of the entire contents of the database (those that aren't marked as private) from the front-end.
